parameters.source_text:
27. Mr. Dorone is a 22-year-old man who sustained a subdural hematoma and a brain contusion in a motor vehicle accident. He needs blood in order to have the necessary lifesaving surgery done. His parents refuse to allow the transfusion based on their religious beliefs.
What should be done?
a. Honor the parents’ wishes and do not give the blood.
b. Give the blood.
c. Wait for a formal hearing with a judge and a court.

data.vignette: A 22-year-old man is brought in after a motor vehicle crash with a subdural hematoma and brain contusions. He is intubated and sedated. He cannot participate in decisions. Neurosurgery recommends urgent decompression tonight to prevent worsening brain injury. He has ongoing blood loss and his team expects he may need transfusion during the operation. His parents are his default surrogates. They refuse any blood products based on their religious beliefs. There is no advance directive, and friends cannot say whether he shares the same refusal. The surgeons can attempt a blood-sparing approach, but it may limit what they can safely do if bleeding becomes significant. Hospital counsel confirms that either treating under emergency authority or honoring the surrogate refusal is legally permissible in this setting.
data.choice_1: Proceed with transfusion and emergent surgery despite the parents’ refusal.
data.choice_2: Perform emergent surgery without transfusion and honor the parents’ refusal.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften wording that implies one option is medically correct. Rephrase “Neurosurgery recommends urgent decompression tonight to prevent worsening brain injury” to “Neurosurgery advises decompression tonight because delaying could lead to further neurologic deterioration.” Replace “it may limit what they can safely do if bleeding becomes significant” with a more neutral description such as “it may constrain intraoperative options if bleeding becomes significant.” Avoid framing transfusion as the only ‘safe’ approach; instead state that transfusion would provide a margin of safety if major hemorrhage occurs.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: As written, ‘ongoing blood loss’ in a polytrauma patient undergoing emergent craniotomy makes a no-transfusion plan feel close to nonviable, risking an implausible/one-sided dilemma. Add stabilizing details that make both pathways realistically defensible (e.g., bleeding source controlled, hemodynamics currently stable, hemoglobin acceptable, estimated operative blood loss uncertain; availability of blood-sparing measures such as TXA, cell salvage if acceptable, meticulous hemostasis, permissive hypotension where appropriate, iron/erythropoietin not applicable acutely). Clarify whether the parents’ faith is one that typically refuses transfusion (e.g., Jehovah’s Witness) and that blood-sparing neurosurgery is technically feasible though higher risk.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: The statement “Hospital counsel confirms that either treating under emergency authority or honoring the surrogate refusal is legally permissible” is too broad without minimal conditions. Add a brief clarifier that this is in a jurisdiction where (a) physicians may provide life-saving treatment in an emergency when patient preferences are unknown, and (b) surrogate refusals are generally honored unless clearly contrary to the patient’s known wishes, and that risk management has advised both options are legally defensible given the uncertainty about the patient’s beliefs. Alternatively, specify that a rapid court order is not feasible tonight, so the team must act under existing emergency/surrogate standards.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options genuinely defensible (not ‘transfuse is obviously right’). Reduce one-sidedness by: (1) specifying that transfusion is anticipated but not certain (blood loss could be limited), and that a no-transfusion attempt has a reasonable chance of success with aggressive blood conservation; (2) adding a concrete moral cost to overriding the parents (e.g., could cause profound distress, long-term mistrust, potential spiritual harm claims, institutional precedent concerns), and a concrete moral cost to honoring refusal (risk of intraoperative exsanguination, inability to complete decompression or manage hemorrhage). Also consider stating there is credible evidence he may share the belief (e.g., parents report prior discussions, religious community involvement) but it is not confirmed—this keeps the uncertainty ethically live.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Strengthen the patient-centered autonomy side of the conflict. Add concrete evidence that the *patient* likely shares the refusal (e.g., a wallet card/bracelet stating refusal of blood, prior documented refusal in the chart, or parents identified as formally appointed health care proxies who report consistent past statements by the patient). Alternatively, if you want uncertainty to be central, explicitly frame the ethical tension as acting on incomplete knowledge of the patient’s values (e.g., conflicting accounts from friends/partner) so the autonomy vs beneficence conflict is not merely “parents’ beliefs vs saving him.”

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify who has decisional authority and what is ethically contested independent of local law. Remove/soften the line that hospital counsel says both options are legally permissible (it invites legal-technical interpretation). Instead, specify the ethically relevant facts: patient lacks capacity; parents are default surrogates; patient’s prior wishes are unknown/ambiguous; surgery is time-sensitive; transfusion may be needed intra-op. Then explicitly state the two clinician paths as a value tradeoff: override surrogate refusal in an emergency vs treat within the refusal and accept higher risk. This will reduce grader disagreement about what the case is ‘really’ testing.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Make both options ethically defensible with real costs on both sides. Currently, because the patient’s own wishes are unknown, proceeding with transfusion reads as the obvious choice (life-saving beneficence), making ‘honor refusal’ look like avoidable harm. To restore balance, add one or more of: (1) evidence the patient likely shares the refusal (refusal card, prior statement), making transfusion a serious violation; (2) a clinically plausible blood-conservation plan that could reasonably succeed but is not guaranteed (cell salvage acceptable to the faith, antifibrinolytics, meticulous hemostasis, staged procedure), so choice 2 is not simply ‘accept preventable death’; (3) specify that transfusion is not certainly required but may be needed if bleeding becomes severe—so the dilemma is whether to pre-authorize blood and proceed vs commit to no blood and accept constraints; (4) articulate the moral costs of transfusing beyond ‘parents object’ (irreversible violation of deeply held beliefs/identity; potential long-term distrust/trauma for family; institutional integrity around honoring refusals).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or balance phrasing that implies one option is clearly safer/medically correct. For example, change “to prevent worsening brain injury” to a more neutral statement such as “for time-sensitive decompression due to concern for rising intracranial pressure.” Replace “it may limit what they can safely do” with balanced language acknowledging uncertainty and tradeoffs (e.g., “a bloodless approach may constrain intraoperative options if hemorrhage is difficult to control; transfusion may reduce physiologic risk but would override surrogate refusal and carries standard transfusion risks”). Avoid value-laden verbs like “honor” in the choices; use neutral verbs like “follow/accept.”

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make each choice a neutral, single-action plan and avoid emotionally valenced wording. Also clarify that transfusion would be used only if clinically required. Example rewrites (10–15 words each):
- Choice 1: “Proceed with emergent decompression and authorize intraoperative transfusion if clinically required.”
- Choice 2: “Proceed with emergent decompression using a bloodless strategy and forgo transfusion.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
As written, Choice 1 is framed as clearly beneficent/standard ("prevent worsening brain injury"), while Choice 2 is framed as potentially unsafe ("limit what they can safely do"). This asymmetry makes Choice 1 feel obviously correct.

Edits to balance:
- Remove/soften language implying decompression + transfusion is clearly the medically correct path (e.g., change "to prevent worsening brain injury" to "to reduce risk of further injury" and avoid implying inevitability).
- Add ethically/clinically serious costs to Choice 1 beyond parental objection (e.g., risk of violating the patient’s likely religious identity if he shares it; potential long-term moral injury, loss of trust, and future refusal of care).
- Add plausible clinical/ethical rationale supporting Choice 2 (e.g., bloodless surgery team available; cell-saver/antifibrinolytics; surgeon believes transfusion may be avoidable; transfusion not certainly needed, only possible; the operation can be staged/limited).
- Add meaningful costs to Choice 2 that are not just "it’s unsafe"—frame as accepting higher risk of intra-op instability/aborting surgery, potential neurological worsening/death.
- Clarify that friends describe him as recently more devout/less devout or that his own views are genuinely unknown (not implicitly opposite of parents).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
The decision space is not truly binary because obvious middle paths exist that could defuse the dilemma:
- Attempt emergent decompression using maximal blood conservation, with a pre-specified intraoperative trigger to transfuse only if death is imminent.
- Seek rapid court order/ethics consult before incision (even if short) or contact an alternate surrogate; or delay surgery briefly for capacity assessment if sedation can be lightened.
- Use blood fractions/alternatives acceptable to some religions; use autologous cell salvage.

Edits to make it genuinely binary:
- Explicitly rule out time for court/ethics review (e.g., imminent herniation signs; OR available only now; waiting risks irreversible injury).
- State that a specialized bloodless neurosurgery/anesthesia team and cell-saver are not available tonight (or are available only if transfusion is off the table), so a conditional plan isn’t feasible.
- Tighten the choice wording to "Authorize transfusion if needed intraoperatively" vs "Place a hard 'no blood' order even if exsanguinating," making it clear conditional transfusion is not permitted under Choice 2.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
This scenario risks being overridden by common legal/ethical standards: in many jurisdictions, emergent life-saving treatment may proceed when patient wishes are unknown and surrogate refusal is not clearly aligned with patient preferences—making Choice 1 closer to a default standard.

Edits to keep it in a gray zone:
- Add a fact pattern that makes it plausible the patient shares the refusal (e.g., wallet card indicating refusal, prior documented refusal in another hospital, or friends report he expressed similar beliefs), while still leaving genuine uncertainty.
- Alternatively, specify the jurisdiction/institution policy is ambiguous for adult patients with unknown wishes and religious surrogate refusals, and that clinicians have seen both approaches upheld.
- Remove/qualify "counsel confirms either is legally permissible" and instead state counsel says both carry legal risk/uncertainty or depend on clinician judgment about substituted judgment vs best interests.

data.vignette: A 22-year-old man is brought in after a motor vehicle crash with a subdural hematoma and brain contusions. He is intubated and sedated and lacks decision-making capacity. CT and exam suggest rising intracranial pressure, and neurosurgery advises decompression tonight; delaying until morning could leave him with irreversible neurologic injury. His other bleeding has been controlled, his blood pressure is stable, and transfusion might not be needed, but it could become necessary if hemorrhage is difficult to control. His parents are the default surrogates and refuse any donor blood products as Jehovah’s Witnesses. They report he recently began attending services and told them he would refuse blood, but he never completed paperwork. A friend says he was considering the faith but was not committed. A court order cannot be obtained in time, and hospital counsel says either course is legally permissible under local emergency and surrogate standards.
data.choice_1: Proceed with decompression and authorize transfusion if clinically required intraoperatively.
data.choice_2: Proceed with decompression under a strict no-transfusion order, even if exsanguinating.
